awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Understanding and Fortifying Machine Learning Based Security Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
Preliminary research has demonstrated that by gaining control of the input data or the computation procedures, attackers can render machine learning based security analysis ineffective. The history of cybersecurity suggests that such attacks will become more prevalent in the real-world soon. This project undertakes the challenge of developing a systematic, foundational, and practical framework to understand attacks, quantify vulnerabilities, and fortify machine learning based security analytics. The framework's effectiveness is evaluated and demonstrated in realistic, user-facing environments, using real malware datasets. This project aims to fundamentally change how machine learning based systems will be designed, developed and deployed for security and malware analytics, cybersecurity more broadly, and numerous other application areas in science, education, and technology, as the use of machine learning is ubiquitous. The findings can lead to new breeds of adaptive defense systems that are highly resilient to current and future security attacks, helping protect the nation and its citizens from cyber harm.

This project combines multiple novel ideas synergistically, organized into four inter-related research thrusts: (1) machine learning theoretical framework, based on machine teaching and active learning, for understanding attacks, quantifying vulnerabilities, and measuring the capabilities of adversaries and model robustness; (2) algorithmic techniques for machine learning resilience, to adaptively counter adversaries' feature and sample manipulation strategies; (3) extensive evaluation of the identified attack and defense strategies with real and mutated malware datasets, on existing security systems, and demonstrate the improved attack resilience of the new, fortified machine learning system; (4) system-level countermeasures in real-world user-facing security analysis environments.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This research project aimed to fundamentally change how machine learning based systems will be designed, developed and deployed for security and malware analytics, enabling new breeds of defense systems that are highly resilient to current and future security attacks, helping protect the nation and its citizens from cyber harm.

Our research has resulted in a large number of significant research results (26 publications at top venues, e.g., Neurips, ICML, CCS, USENIX Security, WWW, CVPR, KDD, VIS), practical deployments, and 8 open-source tools and systems that are immediately available for people to use, such as:

* Breakthrough Techniques for Understanding AI Model Vulnerabilities: AVPASS discovers the detection model of Android malware detection systems (i.e., antivirus software); ShapeShifter is the first targeted physical attack (highlighted by DARPA as state-of-the-art approach); SHIELD is fast and practical defense for computer vision models (won KDD Audience Appreciation Award, Runner-up); 

* Novel datasets and tools: TIGER for evaluating graph robustness (integrated into the free Accelerated Data Science Teaching Kit through NVIDIA?s DLI program that has reached over 8,000 educators worldwide); MalNet is the largest graph- and image-based security datasets (https://www.mal-net.org).

* Survey on state-of-the-art Deepfakes research: our comprehensive survey provides readers with a deep understanding of how deepfakes are created and detected, the current trends and advancements, the shortcomings of the current defense solutions, and the areas which require further research and attention.

* Scalable Visual Discovery for Trustworthy AI: Summit (https://fredhohman.com/summit/) and NeuroCartography (https://poloclub.github.io/neuro-cartography/) scalably summarize and visualize learned concepts; Bluff pinpoints model vulnerabilities (https://github.com/poloclub/bluff).

This project has supported and trained multiple PhD and undergraduate students working at the intersection of and across machine learning and security. Their research was recognized by multiple prestigious PhD fellowship awards (NASA fellowship, two IBM fellowships, and JPMorgan AI PhD Fellowship). Two PhD students are now tenure-track professors. 


Last Modified: 01/17/2022
Modified by: Duen Horng Chau
